1.7 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
As per section 3.9.1 of VCS standard Version 3.6, the projects are classified as follows:
1) Projects: Less than or equal to 300,000 tonnes of CO2e per year
2) Large projects: Greater than 300,000 tonnes of CO2e per year
Each project activity instances being included under grouped project activity currently have less
than 300,000 tCO2e per year emission reductions, hence these project activity instances are
classified as “Projects”. However in case of any project activity instance, if GHG emission
reductions or removals are greater than 300,000 tonnes of CO2e per year, then project activity
instances are considered as Large projects.
Similarly, the estimated GHG Emission Reductions will depend upon the power generation
capacity of individual project activity instances. The emission reductions achieved as part of
grouped project activity will increase as per addition of new project activity instances in the future.
However, estimated Emission Reduction for the initial project activity instances being included in
the grouped project activity are as follows:

Context: B.6. Emission reductions:

According to the approved methodology AM0029, Version 3
Project emissions
The project activity is on-site combustion of natural gas to generate electricity. The CO emissions from 2
electricity generation (PEy) are calculated as follows:
FC : is the total volume of natural gas or other fuel ‘f’ combusted in the project plant or other startup fuel f,y
(m3 or similar) in year(s) ‘y’
COEF : is the CO emission coefficient (tCO /m3 or similar) in year(s) for each fuel and is obtained as: f,y 2 2
COEF = ΣNCVy x EFCO x OXIDf f,y 2f,f,y
Where:
NCVf,y : is the net calorific value (energy content) per volume unit of natural gas in year ‘y’
(GJ/m3) as determined from the fuel supplier, wherever possible, otherwise from local or national data;

MWh annually to be exported to the JAMALI grid that would have been otherwise generated from
fossil-­fuel power plants. The 3 x 60 MW installed capacity generates an average of 104,620 tCO 2
emission reduction credits per year.

3 The project lifetime is based on the design life of the ditches. The design lifetime of the ditches in this project is 30 years, so the project

4 Section 3.8 of the VCS Standard v4.2 states that “The project crediting period is the time period for which GHG emission reductions or
removals generated by the project are eligible for issuance as VCUs.” According to the Methodology of Methane emission reduction by adjusted
water management practice in rice cultivation, the time when the project produces emission reductions is the start time of land preparation.
And the land preparation means the start of a rice season. The main activity of this project is emission reduction due to adjusted water regime
during rice cultivation, which means emission reduction for each year only occurred thought the rice growing season. Therefore, although the
crediting period in 2018 does not start from 1st January, it has already included the whole rice growing season in a year.

A.1. Brief description of the project activity: >>
>>
The project activity is being undertaken to harness the available wind potential in Jaisalmer District vis-
a-vis development of local economy. The project activity establishes 12 x 1250 kW (15MW) Suzlon
Wind Energy Generators(WEG) at Satta,Gorera &Pithala villages in Jaisalmer district of Rajasthan.
These WEGs are interconnected to 33 KV end of 220 KV Grid Sub Station (GSS) Mada in Jaisalmer
.District and commissioned on 29th Sept.07.Total, 100% of electricity generated by 12 Nos of 1250kW
(15 MW) Suzlon make WEGs at Satta,Gorera & Pithala villages will be sold to Ajmer DISCOM In totality
as stated in the registered PDD, the project is displacing equivalent amount of grid power..

who is the only project participant of the project under reference.

VCS Project Description
The Southern Regional Grid of India has been considered within the project
boundary. The carbon intensity of the various GHG emission sources
considered under this header, i.e., the Southern Grid generation mix has
been calculated by the Central Electricity Authority, Government of India
(please refer to the section 4.2 of the VCS PD for details).
Furthermore, there are no GHG sequestration sinks or storage reservoirs to be
considered for the emission reduction computation for the project activity.
Identifying GHG sources, sinks and reservoirs for the baseline scenario and for
the project:
The various GHG emission sources, sinks and reservoirs are identified for any GHG
abatement project within its project boundary. The project boundary for the project
activity under consideration encompassing various GHG emission sources for the
baseline as well sink and reservoirs is identified as follows:
Table 7: GHG emission sources, sinks and reservoirs
The spatial extent of this project activity includes the project site and all the power
plants connected physically to the electricity system that the VCS power project
activity is connected to. As mentioned under paragraph 31 of ‘Annex-C’6 of the
simplified Modalities and Procedures for small-scale project activities’, “The project
boundary shall encompass significant anthropogenic emissions by sources of
greenhouse gases under the control of the project participants that are reasonably
attributable to the project activity.”
The project boundary thus encompasses the physical, geographical site of the
renewable generation source, which includes the Wind Turbine Generators, the
connected metering equipment for each generator and substation, and the grid which
is used to transmit the generated electricity. Since the project power generated from
the project activity is being supplied to the nearby local grid of the Southern region,
Southern regional grid has been chosen as the grid system for the baseline
calculation.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
The project boundary encompasses also the project electricity system(s) and Heat/steam
generation system that the PO plant is connected to. The spatial extent of the project electricity
system consists of the power plants that are physically connected through transmission and
distribution lines to the project activity and that can be dispatched without significant transmission
constraints. The project is connected to the Glow grid which in turn is connected to the national
grid. Therefore, the national grid is considered as the ultimate connected grid. The spatial extent
for the heat (steam) system is similar, including the heat/steam generating systems that are
physically connected to the project activity and that can be displaced without significant
constraints. The heat (steam) requirements of the project are met by the steam extracted from the
cogeneration plants of Glow grid. As the emissions get accounted in the electricity component
therefore to avoid double counting and applying conservative principle the emission factor for
steam has been considered as zero. The fuel requirement is for incineration purpose. Natural gas
is being used as the fuel.
For the CHPO-chlor-alkali process (baseline scenario), the spatial extent of the project boundary
is defined as follows:

1.8 Descriptionof theProject Activity
The Improved Forest Management (IFM) project activity is located in Hongshan County, Suizhou
City, Hubei Province of China. The annual average temperature is 15.4 ℃ and the annual
averageprecipitationis960mm.
The project activity includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in 5,562
subcompartments spreading over Wangjiatai country, Liangtinghe country, Baiguofan country,
Zhoujiazui country, Zhuji country, Huangjiafan country, Peijiayan country, Yunlin country,
Huanglongsi country, Baoji country, Dianzihe country, Paoji country, Gaojianshan country,
Guanyintang country, Guihuayuan country, Guoji country, Huyantao country, Jimingsi country,
Jieshanchong country, Maocifan country, Qiaohe country, Qinglongmiao country, Sanshenmiao
country, Shuanghejie country, Sishan country, Wangheshan country, Wenquan country,
Wushenggong country, Xujiachong country, Yutingling country, Zhoujiawan country by the
conversion of logged to protected forest. All the subcompartments had the legal right to harvest
issued by local forest bureau before the implementation of the project activity. Before 2015, they
were all forests which the trees could be logged and sold once reached the cutting rotation age
based on a timber harvest plan. After 2015, they are all converted to protected forests. Zhejiang
ZhongzhengForestryDevelopmentCo.,LtdisinchargeofapplyingVCSproject.
The purpose of strata is to improve accuracy and reduce the sampling cost. The strata is usually
based on the tree species, age and canopy density, but it does not mean all these factors should
be considered for all projects, more strata means more workload and cost. For this project, the
factor of species for strata could reduce the variation within the same stratum and reach the
accuracylevelof90%undercertaindegreeoffreedom.Sothestrataarereasonableandfeasible.
Allthesubcompartmentsaredividedinto4stratabasedonthetreespecies.

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.1
Long Term Average (LTA) Calculation
The Long-Term Average (LTA) has been calculated by following the VCS Guidelines of Section 3.2.21 of VCS
Program Standard v4.33 and AFOLU Guidance: Example for Calculating the Long Term Average Carbon
Stock for ARR Projects with Harvesting4. The ARR project activity has crediting period of 20 years which will
be renewed four times making the total crediting period of 100 years. Only plantations under Mahogany
(Swietenia macrophylla) and Teak (Tectona grandis) have been considered for the LTA calculation. This is
because on these two species will be subjected to harvested.
1) Establish the period over which the long-term average GHG benefit shall be calculated – The harvesting
of the species Mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and Teak (Tectona grandis) is expected on 21st year.
2) Determine the expected total GHG benefit of the project for each year of the established time period. For
each year, the total GHG benefit is the to-date GHG emission reductions or removals from the project
scenario minus baseline scenario.
3) Sum the total GHG benefit of each year over the established time period
4) Calculate the average GHG benefit of the project over the established time period.
The following equation to calculate the long-term average GHG benefit:
Where:
LA = The long-term average GHG benefit
PEt = The total to-date GHG emission reductions and removals generated in the project scenario (tCO e). 2
Project scenario emission reductions and removals shall also consider project emissions of CO , N O, CH 2 2 4
and leakage.
BE = The total to-date GHG emission reductions and removals projected for the baseline scenario (tCO e) t 2
t = Year
n = Total number of years in the established time period

Context: 4.2 Quantifying GHG emissions and/or removals for the
baseline scenario:
Baseline emissions are calculated with combined baseline emission factor and the net
electricity delivered to the grid by the project.
According to the FSR of the project, the average annual net Electricity Export is
estimated to be 211,080 MW h while the actual measured Electricity Export in 2006,
2007 and 2008 were 149,514, 219,545, 187,980 MWh. Hence the actual annual and
estimated baseline emission of the project in the first crediting period are calculated as
below.
From Apr. 1, 2006 to Dec.31, 2006
BE = EG × EF = 149,514 × 0.8712 × 275/365 = 98,139 t CO e y y y 2
From Jan 1, 2007 to Dec.31, 2007
BE = EG × EF = 219,545 × 0.8712 = 191,267 t CO e y y y 2
From Jan 1, 2008 to Dec.31, 2008
BE = EG × EF = 187,980 × 0.8712 =163,768 t CO e y y y 2
From 2009 to 2015 annually
BE = EG × EF = 211,080 × 0.8712 = 183,893 t CO e y y y 2
From Jan.1, 2016 to Mar.31, 2016
BE = EG × EF = 211,080 × 0.8712 ×91/366 = 45,722 t CO e y y y 2

Soil organic carbon
Estimations of soil organic carbon (SOC) stocks were done in accordance to the “Tool for the estimation of
change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the implementation of A/R CDM project activity”. As suggested
by the tool, it is assumed that the implementation of the project activity increases the SOC content of the
lands from the pre-project level to the level that is equal to the steady-state SOC content under native
vegetation. The increase in SOC content in the project scenario takes place at a constant rate over a period
of 20 years from the year of planting. The project meets the applicability conditions of this tool in the area
managed with Pine plantations:
• the areas of land to which the tool is applied do not fall into wetland category, do not contain
organic soils and are not subject to any of the land management practices and application of
inputs listed in Tables 1 and 2 of the tool;
• Since the land use prior to project start was grassland, only Table 2 applies. For the
temperate warm moist climate region corresponding to the project activity, none of the three
combinations included in Table 2 are applicable;
• litter remains on site and is not removed and soil disturbance is in accordance with
appropriate conservation practices, limited to site preparation and not repeated within 20
years.
Table 19. Parameters used for estimation of SOC

reference SOC. As per the tool, a loss in SOC (SOC ) is applied in the case that soil disturbance LOSS,i
occurs on more than 10 per cent of the land area, which is the case of Weyerhaeuser Uruguay project.

The project activity meets the eligibility criteria to use simplified modalities and procedure for small-

As per the decision 17/CP.7 Para 43, a CDM project activity is additional if anthropogenic emissions of
greenhouse gases by sources are reduced below those that would have occurred in the absence of the
registered CDM project activity.
Further referring to Attachment A to Appendix B document of indicative simplified baseline and

shall provide a qualitative explanation to show that the project activity would not have occurred anyway,
at least one of the listed barrier should be demonstrated in concrete terms to show that the activity is

National Policies relevant to the project activity
The Government of India enacted the Electricity Act in the year 2003 to harmonize and rationalize the
provisions in the then existing laws in India. The Act consolidated the laws relating to generation,
transmission, distribution, trading and use of electricity. With the Enactment of the act, the then existing
laws viz, The Indian Electricity Act 1910, The Electricity Supply Act, 1948 and The Electricity
Regulatory Commissions Act, 1998 were repealed. The Electricity Act 2003 was in force at the time of
the completion of the baseline study for the PDD.
The Gujarat Electricity Regulatory Commission (GERC), had issued a draft tariff order on Wind Energy
on the 17th of June 2009 1 wherein a tariff of Rs. 3.55/kWh has been suggested and which has been used
in the analysis.
Investment Analysis
The project activity involves setting up of 14.85 MW of wind power in Gujarat which will be supplied to
the state electricity grid. The benchmark analysis method has been selected to depict the investment
analysis as the project activity has a revenue source other than CDM revenue.
This is one of the first steps being undertaken by Powerica with the motive of being an independent wind
power producer exporting the generated electricity from its wind farm to the regional electricity system
i.e. NEWNE. Since the project involved 100% equity, Powerica consecutively sought an equity returns
based benchmark applicable to independent power producers in the country implementing similar
projects.
An investment analysis of the project activity was conducted with post tax equity Internal Rate of Return
(IRR) as the financial indicator. IRR is one of the known financial indicators used by banks, lending
institutions and project developers for decision making. The benchmark IRR for the project has been
chosen as 14.76 %. The value has been arrived at following the Capital Asset Pricing Model.

generation with predominantly fossil fuel based power plants5 by renewable electricity. The
emission reduction ER y due to project activity during a given year y is estimated as the
difference between baseline emissions (BE ), project emissions (PE ) and emissions due to y y
leakage (L ), as per the formula given below: y
ER = BE – PE - LE y y y y

1.6 Project Crediting Period
The VCS project crediting period for the Makira project will be of thirty years, stretching from January
1st 2005 to December 31st 2034. A detailed financial plan for managing the Makira project over the
entire project period can be found in annex 6. Projections for expenses in this plan are based on the
Makira management plan developed by WCS and approved by MEF in 2010, while expected
revenues are based on current negotiations with potential buyers and experience from previous sales.
First sales of emission reduction carbon credits, marketed through the Conservation International
Centre for Environmental and Leadership in Business, were approved by the Ministry of Environment,
Water and Forests in early December 2004 and again in 2008 (cf section 1.12.3).
1.7 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
The implementation of the project will generate an estimated 38,016,930 tons of CO equivalents in 2
emission reductions (t CO -e) over the 30-year crediting period (cf. table 1). This corresponds to 2
annual emissions reductions of 1,267,231 tons of CO equivalent per year and the Makira project can 2
therefore be considered as a VCS mega project (more than 1,000,000 t CO -e/y emission reductions). 2
In order to account for non-permanence risks associated with the Makira AFOLU project and in
accordance with the VCS permanence risk assessment tool, 13% of the estimated net change in the
project’s carbon stocks (baseline stocks minus stocks in the project case) will be set aside in a risk
buffer account and not sold (cf. section 3.5 and annex 5). This amounts to a total set aside of
5'517'948 tons of CO equivalents or an annual mean of 183,932 tons of CO equivalents. 2 2

Identifying GHG sources, sinks and reservoirs for the
baseline scenario and for the project:
The various GHG emission sources, sinks and reservoirs are identified for any GHG
abatement project within its project boundary. The project boundary for the project
activity under consideration encompassing various GHG emission sources for the
baseline as well sink and reservoirs is identified as follows:
Table 11: GHG emission sources, sinks and reservoirs
The spatial extent of this project activity includes the project site and all the power
plants connected physically to the electricity system that the VCS power project
activity is connected to. As mentioned under paragraph 31 of ‘Annex-C’14 of the
simplified Modalities and Procedures for small-scale project activities’, “The project
boundary shall encompass significant anthropogenic emissions by sources of
greenhouse gases under the control of the project participants that are reasonably
attributable to the project activity.”
The project boundary thus encompasses the physical, geographical site of the
renewable generation source, which includes the Wind Turbine Generators, the
connected metering equipment for each generator and substation, and the grid which
is used to transmit the generated electricity. Since the project power generated from
the project activity is being supplied to the nearby local grid of the Southern region,
Southern regional grid has been chosen as the grid system for the baseline
calculation.

Context: 5.2 Project Emissions
Emissions Caused by the Project
The emissions caused by the Project are considered zero. As addressed in the PD, this is
due to the manner in which the Project is operated, such as: no vehicles, manual labor
conducted by the small-hold farmers on their own land, restrictions on chemical fertilizers, no
clearing of baseline trees and minimal disturbance of the ground for planting.
Project Removal Calculations
The following provides the step-by-step procedure used to determine the Project GHG
removals:
Step 1. Because of the difference in species and age of the trees and location, ownership
and management of the project areas, each project area is monitored. They are
documented in the "PA Summary" worksheet of Appendix 14. The location of each PA was
obtained with a GPS and is also provided in the "PA Summary" worksheet of Appendix 14.
The boundary of each project area was obtained using a GPS and provided in PD Appendix
03. The area was calculated and is listed with each project area in the "PA Summary"
worksheet of Appendix 14.
Step 2. The strata for the ex-post estimation of the actual net greenhouse gas removals was
done by species and year similar to the ex-ante estimate as described in PD Section 3.2.
Stratification was done within each individual project areas. The area of a stratum in a
project area ("Area of a Stratum (ha)") was determined by multiplying the area of project area
(see Step 1) by the percentage of trees of that stratum in the respective project area. The
results are provided in the "Ex-post Strata" worksheet of Appendix 14.
Step 3. Where a tree species exceeded 10% of the total tree inventory, it was assigned to a
Major Strata. All other tree species were assigned to an "Other" strata. Based on the
tabulations in Appendix 14, there are four major strata: eucalyptus, grevillea, cypress and
other.
Step 4. Allometric equations were used to convert DBH values to biomass. An allometric
equation for each Major Strata was identified. If a species specific equation for a Major
Strata was unavailable, it used the "Other" equation as a default. Allometric equations were
researched and the most appropriate ones identified by the Proponent were assigned to the
major strata. Because no better allometric equation could be found for grevillea and cypress,
they were assigned to the "Other" equation. The following is the assignment.
Eucalyptus13: Log Y = -2.43 + 2.58 Log C
13 DH Ashton, “The Development of Even-aged Stands in Eucalyptus regnans F. Muell. in Central Victoria,” Australian Journal
of Botany, 24 (1976): 397-414, cited by Tim Pearson, Sandra Brown and David Shoch, in “Assessment of Methods and
21

Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
Grevillea: no species specific equations, will use "Other" equation
Cupressus: no species specific equations, will use "Other" equation
Other (default)14: Y = (0.2035 x DBH2.3196) x 1.2
Where:
Y= aboveground dry matter, kg (tree)-1
DBH = diameter at breast height, cm

Context: 2.2.2 Project Description Deviations
There is a deviation from the PD. In the PD we stated "the operational processes for monitoring
the actual GhG removal by the sinks are for TIST Quantifiers to visit each grove once per year
and, at minimum, once every five years to count trees and collect circumference, GPS and other
data" (Section 4.1.3). TIST Quantifiers are not visiting each PA (grove) once per year.
Quantification Every Five Years: While counting trees and collecting circumference every five
years is a requirement of the methodology (and followed by the Project), visiting every PA every
year was simply an operational goal. Not making annual visits does not impact the applicability of
the methodology, additionality or the appropriateness of the baseline scenario. That it was an
operational goal was clearly stated in Section 4.3.5, "TIST’s internal goal is to quantify each
project area once per year."
There are 17 PAs in this PD and over 6,000 PAs in TIST Uganda. Unfortunately, visiting every
PA every year proved to be too costly to maintain. Instead the entire TIST program in Uganda
was modified and centered on a "Cluster" administrative structure. A Cluster is a group of Small
Groups within walking distance that has their own local leadership. It is where Small Groups
receive training, voucher payment, share "best practices," share news and newsletters and
discuss quantification issues. A Quantifier is assigned to each Cluster and their scope has been
broadened to include training and assisting Cluster leaders as they rotate into new positions. The
Cluster provides an alternate method of gathering intelligence about what is happening at the
Small Group level and to individual groves including information that might assist in monitoring
the actual GhG removal.3 This allows us to get the same information that a Quantifier might get
on a non-quantification visit (i.e. the annual visit) by asking members and their neighbors about
changes, at a more sustainable cost. The ideal schedule for Cluster meetings is one per month,
increasing the frequency of opportunity to learn about changes at the grove level.
Removing Project Activity Instances: While it was expected that there would be loss of trees
from the PD due to harvest, etc.,4 the loss of PAs was not addressed. When a member or Small
Group quits or harvests their trees, or if a PA is found to fall within one of the “remove” categories
l through v in section 2.1, above, they are no longer active in the PD. The name of the grove is
3 This includes examples such as if an SG or an SG member has quit or if there has been a major loss
from fire, pest, harvest, etc. The type of information collected is reflected in the monitoring spreadsheets
where we have indicated an issue with the project area (removed or pending) and zeroed out the carbon
for this verification.
4 See section 4.3.3 of the PD: “since ex post carbon calculations are based on current tree counts, any

kept on the monitoring spreadsheet (Appendix 11), the reason for the removal is given in the

from the PA is zeroed out. By zeroing the carbon, all of the carbon credits previously issued from
the PA are replaced with growth from the existing trees in the PD.

The ex ante projections assume that no deforestation, or other sources of emissions, occurs in the project
in the with-project case, i.e. that park protection activities are successful in preventing land clearing within
the park boundary. Park protection and border patrolling, as well as community awareness programs, are
key components to the project implementation. CIMA has a proven track record from 2003 to 2008, of
effective protection work and conflict resolution.
There are no standard approaches to estimate future leakage attributable to a REDD activity, nor does
the methodology provide detailed guidance. Some leakage due to the project is expected. However, as
detailed in the project description, project implementation focuses on activities that should reduce
leakage, including support to potential leakage agents (i.e. communities in the park buffer zone) in
increasing crop productivity, land zoning and securing land tenure. To be conservative, a 20% annual
leakage rate is used.

• Not occurring : Methane emissions not captured by the project and released to the atmosphere,
due to treatment of entire manure within the project boundary as defined;
• Not occurring : Methane emissions captured but not burned, this would only happen in case of a severe
process failure, monitored if occurring,
as not part of the standard scenario
• Not existent : Emissions from combustion of non-biogenic methane,
as no non-biogenic methane present or used
• Neutralized : emissions from displaced fossil sources through electricity produced and fed into the grid,
as per European double allocation prohibition
• Neutralized : emissions from use of electrical energy to drive plant components, treated as fed into the grid
and received back,

• Neutralized : N O emissions of the manure respectively digestate during storage and application on the 2

as emission factor assumed to be equal
1. CH4 emissions from manure management systems (AMS-III.D Methane Recovery)
No additional GHG emissions do occur by sources in the project scenario. The manure treatment system does not
emit GHG into the atmosphere when the project is installed (with the considerations of B.3).
Therefore the annual methane emissions are reduced to 0 t CO e due to the capture and disposal of methane released 2
from stored manure and agricultural wastes.
2. Replacement of fossil fuels for heating (AMS-I.C Thermal Energy for the user)
No additional GHG emissions do occur by sources in the project scenario. The heat demand is completely covered
by the waste heat of the biogas power plant, and no fossil energy is burned any more. Thus no GHG is emitted into
the atmosphere when the project is installed (with the considerations of B.3).
Therefore the annual methane emissions are reduced to 0 t CO e due to the replacement of fossil fuels for thermal 2
purposes such as heating.
3. Total project activity emissions
The total GHG emissions caused by the project activity is zero.
The net GHG mitigation from the electricity approach (production amount minus operating demand) is neutralized in
order to avoid conflicts with the Act of March 2006 amending the Environmental Management Act to implement the
EU linking directive).
The net power balance is very positive, as the electricity production of the biogas power plant is much higher than
the parasitic load of the power plant internal consumers and also much higher than the electricity consumption to be
covered from the grid in case of non-operation.

Context: 5.2 Project Emissions
Emissions Caused by the Project
The emissions caused by the Project are considered zero. As addressed in the PD, this is
due to the manner in which the Project is operated, such as: no vehicles, manual labor
conducted by the small-hold farmers on their own land, restrictions on chemical fertilizers, no
clearing of baseline trees and minimal disturbance of the ground for planting.
Project Removal Calculations
The following provides the step-by-step procedure used to determine the Project GHG
removals:
Step 1. Because of the difference in species and age of the trees and location, ownership
and management of the project areas, each project area is monitored. They are
documented in the "PA Summary" worksheet of Appendix 14. The location of each PA was
obtained with a GPS and is also provided in the "PA Summary" worksheet of Appendix 14.
The boundary of each project area was obtained using a GPS and provided in PD Appendix
03. The area was calculated and is listed with each project area in the "PA Summary"
worksheet of Appendix 14.
Step 2. The strata for the ex-post estimation of the actual net greenhouse gas removals was
done by species and year similar to the ex-ante estimate as described in PD Section 3.2.
Stratification was done within each individual project areas. The area of a stratum in a
project area ("Area of a Stratum (ha)") was determined by multiplying the area of project area
(see Step 1) by the percentage of trees of that stratum in the respective project area. The
results are provided in the "Ex-post Strata" worksheet of Appendix 14.
Step 3. Where a tree species exceeded 10% of the total tree inventory, it was assigned to a
Major Strata. All other tree species were assigned to an "Other" strata. Based on the
tabulations in Appendix 14, there are four major strata: eucalyptus, grevillea, cypress and
other.
Step 4. Allometric equations were used to convert DBH values to biomass. An allometric
equation for each Major Strata was identified. If a species specific equation for a Major
Strata was unavailable, it used the "Other" equation as a default. Allometric equations were
researched and the most appropriate ones identified by the Proponent were assigned to the
major strata. Because no better allometric equation could be found for grevillea and cypress,
they were assigned to the "Other" equation. The following is the assignment.
Eucalyptus13: Log Y = -2.43 + 2.58 Log C
13 DH Ashton, “The Development of Even-aged Stands in Eucalyptus regnans F. Muell. in Central Victoria,” Australian Journal
of Botany, 24 (1976): 397-414, cited by Tim Pearson, Sandra Brown and David Shoch, in “Assessment of Methods and
21

Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
Grevillea: no species specific equations, will use "Other" equation
Cupressus: no species specific equations, will use "Other" equation
Other (default)14: Y = (0.2035 x DBH2.3196) x 1.2
Where:
Y= aboveground dry matter, kg (tree)-1
DBH = diameter at breast height, cm
C = circumference at breast height, cm
ln = natural logarithm
exp = e raised to the power of

Wind power is one of the cleanest sources of renewable energy, with no
associated emissions and waste products. As per the Schedule 1 of Ministry
of Environment and Forests (Government of India) notification9 dated
September 14, 2006, wind power projects do not require an Environmental
Impact Assessment. However, certain foreseen impacts due to the project
activity are discussed below:
Noise Pollution
Most of the wind turbines are in isolated areas or on designated wind zones
and hence do not cause any concern to the residents of the area. In the same
vein, construction activities also have not caused noise pollution due to the
isolated nature of the area.
Water Pollution
There is no gaseous, liquid or solid effluent from the Wind Turbine
Generators. Hence there is no contamination of water bodies due to
operation of Wind Turbine Generators.
Air Pollution
Minimal air pollution might have occurred during the construction of the
Project due to transportation. However, these were not found to affect the
surrounding persons nor the environment in any significant manner. Wind

5 Environmental Impact:
As described in section 1.7 of this Project Description, the land on which the Red
Hills Wind Farm is being constructed is rural agricultural farmland, which is best
suited for pasturing livestock and the cultivation of wheat and cotton crops.
Local development consists primarily of widely dispersed individual farmsteads.
Socioeconomic and environmental activity in the project area will remain
unchanged upon completion of the wind farm construction and operation. No
dislocation of people or wildlife will occur as a result of the project activity.
There are no federal authorizations or permits required for the project that would
entail consultation under Section 7 of the Endangered Species Act, to include the
need to obtain project authorization from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. There
are four federally listed endangered or threatened species that potentially occur in
the general vicinity of the Red Hills Wind Project: the interior least tern, whooping
crane, piping plover, and the Arkansas River shiner. The project activity has been
designed to avoid impacts on the United States waterways.
Acciona Wind Energy USA LLC voluntarily contracted HDR Engineering, Inc.
(HDR) and Western Ecosystems Technology Inc. to complete the environmental
site assessment (ESA) and Biological Assessment of the property proposed for the
Red Hills Wind Project. The environmental assessment was completed by HDR on
January 30, 2008 and the biological assessment was completed by Western
Ecosystems on March 27, 2008.
Western Ecosystems determined that; “The Red Hills project avoids many of the
potential impacts to whooping cranes due to its distal proximity to the main
migratory flyway.” Western Ecosystems also determined that other aforementioned
endangered species were not threatened by the project activity.
Acciona voluntarily contracted Western Ecosystems to conduct a voluntary bat
assessment using acoustic monitoring equipment. Additionally post construction
bat mortality monitoring will take place for one year after operation of the facility
begins. Any bats that are found during these mortality studies will be offered as a
donation to the American Museum of Natural History for their ongoing Genomic
Studies.
Further studies such as the wetlands delineation was conducted on November 26
and 27, 2007, by two HDR biologists. The survey was conducted in accordance
with the Corps of Engineers Wetlands Delineation Manual (Environmental
Laboratory, 1987).
Acciona proposes to implement the following design, siting, and conservation
measures to ensure to that the ecological environment is not affected by the project
activity:
• Turbine Design: Acciona will use monopole, tubular designs that
eliminate avian perching sites. Guy wires will not be used on
turbines. If guy wires are used on the permanent and temporary
meteorological towers within the project, appropriate high visibility
markings will be used.
• Collector Line Design: Acciona will bury the majority (about 88%) of
the collector lines for the project. For the overhead collector line
41

Proprietary and Confidential
segments and the overhead 138 kV transmission line, Acciona will
mark the lines in accordance with methods recommended by the
Avian Power Line Committee (APLIC).
• Transmission Line: Using guidance from APLIC’s Suggested
Practices for Avian Protection on Power Lines, approximately 4 miles
of on-site overhead 138 kV transmission line will be designed to
minimize the potential for bird electrocutions.
• Lighting: The Red Hills Wind Project will use the minimum amount
of lighting as required by Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
Lighting is anticipated to be pulsating red light on the minimum
number of turbines as required by the FAA in order to reduce the
disturbances on the local population.
• Air Impacts: Wind Power plants do not contribute to atmospheric
pollution as no fuel combustion is involved during any stage of the
operation. The primary emissions source for the project will be motor
vehicle exhaust resulting from construction and maintenance of the
project. However, in light of the project activity and the resulting
emission reductions, motor vehicle emissions will be a very minor
emissions source.
• Noise Impacts: Personal protective equipment is provided to workers
involved in construction activity to mitigate the effects of noise
pollution. Taking into consideration the project life cycle, the
magnitude of the impacts during the construction phase are negligible
and exists for a temporary period of time until the end of construction
phase. Therefore, noise pollution will also be a very minor issue and
will not harm the environment.
Acciona recognizes the concerns over the relationship between wind energy
development and the ecological environment of the project activity. As such,
commitments have been made to evaluate and immediately address issues that
impact the project activity area.
42

Proprietary and Confidential
6 Stakeholders’ comments:
Stakeholders for the Red Hills Wind Farm project include landowners, local
residents, local officials, and Acciona staff.
Roger Mills County held public meetings on February 11th and June 16th 2008 to
discuss permitting issues for the Red Hills Wind Farm. During these meetings,
local constituents were provided the opportunity and platform to discuss their
concerns about the project activity.
Each meeting began with a brief progress update for the project activity by the
project developer, construction manager, and other project officials. The overall
reaction can be summarized as positive. The local residents expressed satisfaction
that the project activity has created local employment which is improving the
standard of life as well as socio-economic conditions of the surrounding area.
Moreover, local landowners have expressed satisfaction that the project activity has
led to an increase in land values.
Only one negative issue was raised by one non-participating landowner at the
February 11th meeting. This landowner raised concerns that the turbines were too
close to the fence surrounding his property, which is not in the project activity
area. This concern was investigated by the project developer and it was discovered
that the landowner had mistaken a property survey stake that was about 30 feet
from his fence for a turbine-staked location. This issue was resolved through
further communication with the landowner and was publicly addressed at the June
16th community meeting.
In July 2008, two non-participating landowners from Roger Mills County requested
to meet with the project developer to express concerns that the project activity was
located too close to their property lines. The landowners expressed that they felt
that permitting had occurred without their knowledge and felt that they had been
circumvented in the process. Over the course of a two-hour meeting, it was pointed
out that Acciona had followed the counties permitting guidance and that there were
two public meetings that they did not attend.
These landowners as well as all stakeholders involved in this project activity will be
notified of all future public meetings.
43

Proprietary and Confidential
7 Schedule:
The Red Hills crediting period will begin on the commercial operation date of
October 26, 2008 and will last for 10 years thereafter. The lifespan of the wind
farm is expected to be 20 years after the operational date. The project activity will
not be terminated for any reason, other than for emergencies, until the end of the
operational life. Validation will be complete upon review and approval of this
document. Verification will occur depending on the needs of project participants.
44

Proprietary and Confidential

For this ARR project activity, Face in 1999 commissioned Meijer to carry out a
baseline study whose results show that changes in the carbon stocks for both
above and below ground biomass are expected not to exceed actual net GHG
removals by sinks and are therefore assumed to be zero in the absence of the
project activity. Hence the formula above is only applied to multiply the 5.2 tonnes
of carbon per hectare (adjusted from Meijer, 1999), which is the conservative
value of the carbon stock in the stratum ‘banana plantation’, with the combined
area A of stratum ‘Planted Area’ and ‘Regenerating Area’. The total area to be i
planted during the crediting period is presented in Table 7.2 and has a size of
6,000 hectares. In addition, the Regenerating Area is 2,593 hectares. The
combined area is therefore 8,593 hectares. As the baseline is in a steady state,
there is no increases in GHG removals. See Annex III for details on the estimation,
and the spreadsheet ´ Kibale Baseline Recalculation_082711 ´, which details the
calculation of the mean tree carbon stock in the baseline, based on inventory data
by Meijer in 1999. In addition, the carbon stock changes in dead wood, litter and
soil organic matter are conservatively assumed to be zero based on the
methodology applied.

Context: 4.3 Natural Capital and Ecosystem Services Monitoring Plan
Biodiversity Monitoring Plan (B4.1, B4.2, GL1.4, GL3.4)
Indicators are important in impact assessment because they respond to the basic question “what
should be measured to show that the claimed net social benefits are real and additional?” (Richards &
Panfil 2011) An ideal indicator from the perspective of showing attribution is one that measures an
‘intermediate state’ or assumption between an output and outcome or an outcome and an impact,
clearly showing progress along a causal chain (Richards & Panfil, 2011). Thus, we used our theory of
change logic in the Result Chain diagrams (section Error! Reference source not found.) as the basis
for selecting indicators that factor in attribution. We then decided on the best sampling methods to use
to collect these data to acceptable levels accuracy, precision and cost effectiveness whilst retaining
transparency and simplicity. From this, a Monitoring Plan was developed to guide data collection.
Further, the indicators will be analyzed based on the Pressure-State-Response framework, which also
relies on a causal-chain logic, where threats negatively impact the status/condition of biodiversity, while
87

Project Description: SD VISta Version 1
responses or project interventions reduce pressure. Most Response indicators can be grouped under:
Habitat improvement; Security enhancement; and Improvement of community livelihoods efforts.
Pressure indicators fall under: Human population size and dynamics; Human-wildlife conflict (HWC);
and Incidences including poaching, grazing, encroachment, charcoal and firewood collection amongst
others. Finally, State indicators are grouped into three categories: wildlife (including species presence,
diversity, distribution and movement); vegetation and land-use (including changes in various
vegetation/habitat types, encroachment and fire). Most of the response and pressure indicators
correspond to the social indicators developed in the community monitoring plan (See Section. 4.3.1),
and so data collection follows the protocols outlined therein. On top, we determined 12 indicators not
part of the social indicator set, also classified into three categories: Output 4; Outcome 4; and Impact.
For these new indicators, two main strategies will be used to obtain the data: In-house reporting and
Government records, mostly for output and outcome indicators, and surveys for most impact indicators.
We envision three main aspects of state indicators to measure, each with a distinct set of monitoring
protocols:
Wildlife: wildlife surveys and monitoring for all species – with a focus on HCVs – will be done using
several methods: ranger patrols, camera traps, fecal-DNA analysis, and information from any
independent research projects in the area
Vegetation and Land-use: carbon plot monitoring plots and remote sensing (based on LANDSAT
imagery) and GIS techniques.

1.8 DESCRIPTION OFTHE PROJECTACTIVITY
All sites were barren hills and wastelands at least 10 years prior to the project,the project will not
convert native ecosystems to create GHG credits..The project is to establish forest on the barren
hills and wasteland to generate GHG emission reductions and contribute to local sustainable
development. The project is implemented by about 27,380ha of forest is to be established by
direct planting on barren hills in Nanzhao county, Nanyang City, Henan Province. The project
involves 15 towns of Nanzhao Country, which are Chengguan Town, Chengjiao Town, Liushan
Town, Xiaodian Town, Yunyang Town, Huanghou Town, Taishanmiao Town, Shimen Town,
Sikeshu Town, Nanhedian Town, Baitugang Town, Banshanping Town, Qiaoduan Town,
Mashiping Town, Cuizhuang Town. Aiming to contribute to the local sustainable development,
especially to mitigating the water and soil erosion, 27,380 ha of forest would be established by
direct planting on the barren hills and wasteland. in these 15 towns.Considering the goal of the
project activity, the native species Magnolia and Oak tree are chosen as the target species.
Seedling planting is chosen as the forestation method. Seedling must be robust with developed
rootsystem,hasnomechanicaldamageandnodiseases,andhascompletecrown.
The forestation activities intend to contribute to climate change mitigation through sequestration
of atmospheric CO during biomass growth. The local communities will benefit from the project in 2
enhancingjobopportunities,improvedenvironmentandlandscaperestoration.
1.9 PROJECTLOCATION
The project is located in Nanzhao County, Nanyang City, Henan Province, China. The
geographical coordinates of the project is between 111°55′ and 112°51′ east longitude and
between33°12′and33°43′northlatitude.
ThelocationoftheprojectactivityinHenanProvinceisillustratedinFigure1-1.

In accordance with the selected CDM methodology, the greenhouse gas emissions of the proposed project
activities can be neglected (Section I, paragraph 3). However, in the framework of the VCS, relevant
greenhouse gas emissions of the baseline scenario shall be considered (VCS 2007.1, paragraph 6.3.1).
The baseline studies made by CIRAD (200040; 200141) first described the activities present in the
reference scenario and the project scenario (Table 9) within project boundary, and then listed all GHG
sources related to the activities approached (Table 10).
Table 9: Activities of reference scenario and project scenario.
Table 10: Carbon pools and GHG sources of reference scenario and project scenario.
Emissions from combustion of fossil fuel
The combustion of fossil fuels occurs in both reference and project scenario but the related GHG
emissions are supposed to be higher in the project scenario because of additional activities (reforestation
activities). However, they should be very low and negligible in comparison with CO removals from 2
forest plantations.
The GHG emissions were calculated by following IPCC GL 2006 with the date monitored in the fazenda.
Every year, 2’000 liters of diesel oil are consumed by project activities. Depending on years, a trade-off
exists between activities but global consumption remains similar. By applying IPCC method and default
values (EF = 2.707 kgCO .L-1), a total of 54.14 tCO were emitted during the last 10 years, since Diesel oil 2 2
project start. If this result is compared to the GHG emissions from fossil fuel combustion of the reference
scenario, the net GHG emissions can reasonably be neglected.
Emissions from biomass burning

In the reference scenario, with the continuation of cattle grazing activities, annual fire is a common
practice for pasture management. Fire is used each year in order to stimulate growth of grasses. In terms
of greenhouse gas, CO , CH , CO, NO and N O are emitted. While CO emissions are compensated by 2 4 x 2 2
the regrowth of grasses, the other GHG emissions remain in the atmosphere, representing a GHG source.
In the project scenario such practice is not used as pastures are converted to forest lands. Thus, GHG
emissions from biomass burning in the reference scenario are net GHG emissions, but if accidental fires
occur in the project area. Therefore GHG emissions from biomass burning could represent a relevant
GHG source.
However, such emissions need large amount of biomass burning to be significant. As an example CH is 4
the main GHG released during biomass burning with an emission factor of 67 g.(kg d.m)-1, in comparison
with other GHG that have emissions factors lower than 4 g.(kg d.m)-1. Considering a hypothetical initial
biomass of 30 t d.m.ha-1 in pasture of the project area, which is high, the CH released during biomass 4
burning of the whole project area would be 16 tCO -e each year. Therefore, as GHG emissions from 2
fossil fuel combustion, GHG emissions from biomass burning can reasonably be neglected.
Emissions from enteric fermentation
This item represents the major GHG source inside project in the baseline scenario. As mentioned above,
3’960 heads of cattle pre-existed before project start and then were killed at project start. Thus, the
difference between GHG emissions from enteric fermentation in the reference scenario shall be
significant compared with project scenario.
However, in the project scenario, some animals of neighboring fazendas are present inside project area.
The neighboring animals are authorized inside project area for weed control and to generate additional
incomes from land renting. Thus, some cattle are still present inside project area with a low mean annual
presence of 822 heads since project start.
Therefore, even with animals still present inside project area, the difference of GHG emissions from
enteric fermentation between reference scenario and project scenario will be significant, as a
buffalo emits more than 1 tCO -e.year-1, and therefore will be estimated following IPCC GL 2006 in 2
accordance with VCS recommendations.
Emissions from the decomposition of dead wood
Dead wood is a main compartment in the reference scenario and the project scenario as natural forest was
slashed and burnt by the former landowner in order to open pastures for cattle grazing activities, and the
lying dead wood left on site.
In the reference scenario, dead wood is burnt year after year through pasture management by fire. The
remaining burnt dead wood participates to the process of decomposition. In the project scenario the dead
wood is neither displaced nor burnt. Therefore, it completely participates to the process of decomposition.
In consequence, it can reasonably be argued that GHG emissions from dead wood burning in the
reference scenario are almost equivalent to GHG emissions from dead wood decomposition in the project
scenario considering that CH is the main GHG involved in both processes. 4
Moreover, the inputs of dead wood from the management of forest plantations shall not lead to significant
additional GHG emissions considering the low amounts of GHG released during decomposition of dead

Context: 5.2 Project Emissions
Emissions Caused by the Project
The emissions caused by the Project are considered zero. As addressed in the PD, this is
due to the manner in which the Project is operated, such as: no vehicles, manual labor
conducted by the small-hold farmers on their own land, restrictions on chemical fertilizers, no
clearing of baseline trees and minimal disturbance of the ground for planting.
Project Removal Calculations
The following provides the step-by-step procedure used to determine the Project GHG
removals:
Step 1. Because of the difference in species and age of the trees and location, ownership
and management of the project areas, each project area is monitored. They are
documented in the "PA Summary" worksheet of Appendix 14. The location of each PA was
obtained with a GPS and is also provided in the "PA Summary" worksheet of Appendix 14.
The boundary of each project area was obtained using a GPS and provided in PD Appendix
03. The area was calculated and is listed with each project area in the "PA Summary"
worksheet of Appendix 14.
Step 2. The strata for the ex-post estimation of the actual net greenhouse gas removals was
done by species and year similar to the ex-ante estimate as described in PD Section 3.2.
Stratification was done within each individual project areas. The area of a stratum in a
project area ("Area of a Stratum (ha)") was determined by multiplying the area of project area
(see Step 1) by the percentage of trees of that stratum in the respective project area. The
results are provided in the "Ex-post Strata" worksheet of Appendix 14.
Step 3. Where a tree species exceeded 10% of the total tree inventory, it was assigned to a
Major Strata. All other tree species were assigned to an "Other" strata. Based on the
tabulations in Appendix 14, there are four major strata: eucalyptus, grevillea, cypress and
other.
Step 4. Allometric equations were used to convert DBH values to biomass. An allometric
equation for each Major Strata was identified. If a species specific equation for a Major
Strata was unavailable, it used the "Other" equation as a default. Allometric equations were
researched and the most appropriate ones identified by the Proponent were assigned to the
major strata. Because no better allometric equation could be found for grevillea and cypress,
they were assigned to the "Other" equation. The following is the assignment.
Eucalyptus13: Log Y = -2.43 + 2.58 Log C
13 DH Ashton, “The Development of Even-aged Stands in Eucalyptus regnans F. Muell. in Central Victoria,” Australian Journal
of Botany, 24 (1976): 397-414, cited by Tim Pearson, Sandra Brown and David Shoch, in “Assessment of Methods and
21

Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0
Grevillea: no species specific equations, will use "Other" equation
Cupressus: no species specific equations, will use "Other" equation
Other (default)14: Y = (0.2035 x DBH2.3196) x 1.2
Where:
Y= aboveground dry matter, kg (tree)-1
DBH = diameter at breast height, cm
C = circumference at breast height, cm
